Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Suggestion inline for replacing the Mitaka spec-lite-process description that everyone seems to be in favor of removing.

Patch Set 1:

Please add to commit message:

The TL;DR is: Using bugs doesn't seemed to work. Triaging them was something we did in the drivers meeting which we don't have anymore. Using specs encourages a more distributed review process across core reviewers.  Also ... moving it to the glance-specs repo, we get all our specs listed in the same website.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

It's not clear to me what we're proposing here.

Is there a difference between a regular spec and a light spec?

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I agree with Stuart.  I think the entire section on lines 41-85 needs to be changed to explain what a spec-lite is without any reference to the launchpad process.  The only reference to the old launchpad spec-lite should be that note I suggested inline, just so people can find the old ones if they need to.

Erno, thanks for writing this up.

Patch Set 1:

FWIW I think having to make two separate commits to two different repos for any small change to glance will be a turn off for committers. Similarly, it will double the number of reviews for the change.

I'd certainly think twice about pushing up small commits if I knew there would be a spec (potentially requiring several patches) before I can push up my five line change. For new committers in particular (who may be used to a simpler experience with other projects) it seems like overkill.

We need to balance what the cores would like around administering the project with what encourages people to contribute to the project.

Perhaps just a tag in the commit message to help us find the 'spec-lite' reviews ... maybe with some spec-lite guidelines to ensure a descriptive commit message?

Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

That's good idea actually, especially considering our review bandwidth.

Patch Set 1:

The points Stuart is bringing up align with the ones we used in favor of using LP. 

At this point, after our experience using LP as a tracker for spec-lites, I think I'd prefer glance-specs over it. However, Stuart's proposal of tagging commits is also appealing. 

The downside I see to Stuart's proposal is that we loose the ability to expose those changes without looking into git's log.

I like having a small spec written because it provides a small description about what the change is.

Here's an idea to follow-up on Stuart's proposal:

1. We use commit messages as the place to describe the spec lite. It must be descriptive, follow a specific form and we'll tag it.
2. We discuss spec lites on the proposed change itself and we vote on it directly
3. If it's approved, we run an automated script that creates a spec lite in glance-specs using the commit message and approve it.
4. If it's not approved... oh well. We can offer beers and let Stuart pay.

The above removes the need of an extra step, it provides enough info in the commit itself and it'll allow us to easily keep glance-specs updated with all the lite specs without much effort. We can do the sync every milestone or at the FF time.

Thoughts?

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This seems a bit bureaucratic for a small change.

I think Stuart makes some good points about using the commit message. Under that logic if a change gets accepted then by extension the new behaviour is desired. Then collating this with a script into glance-spec, sounds like a much better way to do it to me.

Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I like Stuart's idea of descriptive commit messages for lite specs. However, I'm wondering if that is inherently limiting a spec-lite to have just one commit associated with it?
It makes a certain sense to expect lite-specs to be addressed by one commit in most cases. But, is that an inherent limitation of this approach and are we okay with it?

Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Will look through this tomorrow and try to get new version reflecting the current workflow updated.

Patch Set 1:

I am a bit hesitant on relying to commit messages for introducing changes that fall under a lite-spec like category. 

I like the fact that Flavio tried to come up with idea that would settle this middle ground but we still have a issue. In the middle of a cycle where you need to reference a piece of work in some other spec (like nova, cross project, etc.) we don't have a reference point.

I don't think all committers are willing to be good on writing long commit messages and neither all reviewers strict on that fact. 

The most important thing that needs to show up as a part of a spec or a lite spec is the idea behind that change: 

    * what's the problem it's trying to solve? 

    * what's the scope of that proposal? 

    * has that been attempted before and where and why failed if so? if it's a carry forward of any work, why, who, when details become relevant.

    * if a bug has triggered a design change, what bug(s) are those?

    * who all are assigned and a point of contact of the feature (more of a product based use case) rather than a simple commit that can be limited in scope

    * who all are affected by the change. is this is design change or something that results in different upgrade, security, access control (policy), notification, etc. behavior?

If we keep relying on commit messages then the original proposal of a spec (feature proposal) has the potential to become redundant over time. Have a logs of such important behavioral changes ensure that we do a health check on the project every so often.

Think of this like your quarterly/biannual regular doctor's visit.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

So, I just wanted to follow up and give more contextual feedback.

I think we need specs and we need a way to reference the change. It might be worth keeping lite-specs in the glance source tree. TBH, I've always been in favor of this. We've documentation related to glance that describes architecture, schema, API etc in the source tree. It would be okay to keep the lite specs here too, I think.

That way we can ensure that the committer and reviewer have a good view of the changes in a single or dependent commits.

Also, we're running into the issue where for lite-specs we don't have a LP items (bug, BP) so auto linking through gerrit commit messages isn't possible. I don't think that's quite discoverable and doesn't even give us the entire picture of the change proposed.

Thoughts?
Uploaded patch set 2.

Patch Set 2:

I don't have a strong opinion, though I think Nikhil raises a good point about tracking.  Maybe we should adjust the lite-specs.rst template to include a URL to a launchpad blueprint, just like we do for full specs?  It's a minor inconvenience for a casual committer.

I appreciate Stuart's point about a barrier to committers, but a small change that is actually a bug can be filed as a bug (and people will probably still try to sneak in features as bugs).  Some small changes actually require a lot of discussion -- I'm thinking here of the bug reported about users allowed to delete a 'deactivated' image.  I think the original patch was less than 5 lines, but has required a lot of discussion about changing behavior and the original image deactivation spec.  So I think we need something like the process Erno has outlined.

I guess my main concern about barriers to entry is that if all spec-lites are in one file, aren't we going to have merge conflicts out the wazoo?  That's a fairly unpleasant experience for a causal committer.

Patch Set 2:

I like Brian's suggestion to include a blueprint URL for tracking/tagging purposes. And, yeah, the merge conflicts is a definite possibility. Is there a specific reason we want to keep all spec-lites in one file? 

Well, I guess if we have spec-lites in their own files it may be hard to distinguish between a full-spec vs spec-lite without looking at the contents. If that's a concern, how about keeping all spec-lites in one sub-directory?

On an unrelated note, I think we should try and do process-oriented changes like this before the cycle opens (to whatever extent possible). It won't be a pleasant experience for anyone who is trying to get in small change and has been instructed to follow the spec-lite process that isn't clearly defined yet.

Patch Set 2:

I think to avoid the problem of it blocking changes why don't we flip the process?

1. Submit patch.
2. Deemed to require spec-lite.
3. Spec-lite created.
4. Change is reviewed normally (whilst checking spec-lite exists).
4b. Approver of change then 2a's spec-lite.

This would cause the spec-lite to be less of a blocker for changes and become more of a tool for documenting them.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

It'd fair to document the work to be in progress while working on spec lite rather making that sequential process. I will find a place to put this in highlight so that people know how to work on things.

Having said that, the purpose of any spec whether lite or not is to provide a check on the inappropriately changing behavior of the code or, a service as a whole. So, we need the spec lite's colorful way (however colorful it may be today) to bring forward such points so that cores don't regret +2Wing something. Although, the current pattern of core reviews seems rather optimistic than conservative but that's been the due to low core b/w.

Ultimate solution is to keep working on maintaining good core/reviews balance and I attempt to do that every time I talk to someone interested in Glance.

But to speeden things, I think we can avoid gerrit and go to BPs (specless BPs as they are usually called by other teams) for liter specs.

Make sense?

Now that summit is too close, let's wait till the contributor's meetup when we can finalize the process using a "non-virtual ballot".

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Nikhil, not sure I follow you on your last comment.

Are you proposing not having a spec lite rst file and just do blueprints? 

If so, I'd be curious to know why and also what changed since we last discussed the above. As far as I can remember, there was no objection when this was brought up.

I'm personally against using LP blueprints for a couple of reasons. Perhaps the most relevant is that there's been quite some work on moving away from it and the less we use it the better (IMHO). The only thing we depend on LP for are bugs.

Patch Set 2:

Hey,

I changed the process a bit. More info at http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/glance/2016/glance.2016-05-05-14.00.log.html#l-48 .

Patch Set 2:

More info https://review.openstack.org/#/c/315339/
